text: I import U.S.-made networking equipment into the EU. Draft a contract clause for new purchase orders that specifically addresses the risk that the EU might apply a carbon-related border tariff to U.S. goods before 2028 (who pays, price adjustments, termination rights). Keep it commercially realistic.
proposition: The European Union will impose carbon tariffs on US goods before January 1, 2028.
response_text:
Suggested contract clause — Carbon-related border adjustments (EU) (applicable to Purchase Orders issued under this Agreement)

1. Definitions
1.1 "Carbon Border Measure" means any customs duty, tariff, tax, levy, surcharge, assessment, reporting obligation or other charge (including any EU Carbon Border Adjustment Mechanism, CBAM, or equivalent) that is imposed by the European Union or an EU Member State on the importation of goods into the EU, or any regulatory scheme that results in a directly payable cash cost on imported goods because of greenhouse gas emissions, which becomes effective prior to 1 January 2028.

2. Notification and Cooperation
2.1 Each Party shall promptly notify the other in writing (within 5 Business Days) of: (a) any announcement, draft or final decision, or other credible information indicating that a Carbon Border Measure will be imposed that affects the Goods; and (b) any demand or invoice from a competent authority for payment of a Carbon Border Measure in respect of the Goods.
2.2 The Parties shall cooperate in good faith and use commercially reasonable efforts to minimize the impact of any Carbon Border Measure (including by providing origin/country-of-origin documentation, emissions data, supplier declarations, registration, or other documents required under the applicable measure).

3. Payment and Allocation of Liability
3.1 Importer of Record. Unless the Parties otherwise agree in writing in the applicable Purchase Order, Buyer shall be the importer of record for imports into the EU and shall initially pay any duties, taxes or charges demanded by customs authorities in order to clear the Goods.
3.2 Reimbursement by Seller. If a Carbon Border Measure imposed prior to 1 January 2028 is assessed and payable in respect of the Goods imported into the EU, and such measure is directly attributable to the manufacture, origin, or reported embedded emissions of the Goods (and not to Buyer’s conduct or classification), Seller shall reimburse Buyer for the amount of that Carbon Border Measure within thirty (30) days after Seller’s receipt of (i) Buyer’s written demand, (ii) a copy of the customs demand/invoice, and (iii) reasonable supporting documentation showing the amount payable and how it relates to the Goods.
3.3 Exception — Seller Mitigation/Compliance. Seller shall not be required to reimburse amounts for a Carbon Border Measure to the extent Seller demonstrates with reasonable evidence that (a) Seller complied with and timely executed all reasonable steps requested by Buyer to avoid or reduce the charge (including furnishing certificates, emissions data, or registration information), and (b) the charge nevertheless arose solely due to Buyer’s classification, instructions, or import practices.

4. Price Adjustment for Future Orders
4.1 If a Carbon Border Measure is imposed in respect of the Goods, Seller may submit a written request to Buyer for an equitable adjustment to the Prices for future Purchase Orders to reflect only the actual additional cash cost of the Carbon Border Measure (no markup). Such request must include documentary evidence of the amount and calculation methodology.
4.2 Buyer shall review the request in good faith and notify Seller within thirty (30) days whether it accepts the proposed adjustment. If Buyer does not accept the proposed adjustment, the Parties shall promptly (and in any event within fifteen (15) days after Buyer’s notice) enter into negotiations in good faith to agree an appropriate price modification. Absent agreement within thirty (30) days after the start of such negotiations, either Party may terminate affected future Purchase Orders under Section 5 below.

5. Termination Rights (affected Orders)
5.1 If a Carbon Border Measure increases Buyer’s landed cost for Goods under any Purchase Order by more than five percent (5%) (measured as the additional Carbon Border Measure divided by the net Price of the Goods for that Purchase Order), and the Parties have not agreed a price adjustment or other mitigation within sixty (60) days after the initial notice under Section 2.1, then Buyer may, at its election, terminate without penalty (including without liability for liquidated damages or forecasted profit) any outstanding Purchase Orders for the affected Goods by written notice to Seller, effective immediately.
5.2 If Seller is the Party that is contractually required under Section 3.2 to reimburse the Carbon Border Measure and fails to reimburse Buyer within thirty (30) days after Buyer’s submission of valid documentation, Buyer may (in addition to other remedies) suspend further performance under outstanding Purchase Orders and terminate any affected Purchase Orders on fifteen (15) days’ written notice.

6. Mitigation and Records
6.1 Each Party shall retain and provide, at the other Party’s reasonable request, records reasonably necessary to substantiate origin, emissions, or other data relevant to the assessment or avoidance of a Carbon Border Measure (subject to confidentiality obligations).
6.2 The Parties shall act reasonably and cooperate in seeking available exemptions, rebates, or alternative customs treatment (including obtaining certificates of origin or upstream supplier attestations) to reduce or eliminate the Carbon Border Measure.

7. General
7.1 The Parties’ rights and obligations under this clause shall apply only to Carbon Border Measures imposed and effective prior to 1 January 2028.
7.2 Nothing in this clause waives either Party’s right to challenge any assessment of duties or to seek recovery from a customs authority where permitted by law.
7.3 This clause allocates the Parties’ commercial allocation of risk only; any tax, customs or legal obligations to governmental authorities shall remain subject to applicable law.

Alternative allocation options (pick one for insertion if you prefer a different commercial split)
A. Buyer-Pays (importer bears all costs). Replace Sections 3.2 and 5 with: “Buyer shall bear all Carbon Border Measures; Seller shall have no reimbursement obligation. Seller will cooperate as set out in Section 2 and 6. Buyer may request a price reduction from Seller if Buyer is required by law to pay and can demonstrate a net increase in Buyer’s cost of more than 10%.” 
B. Shared (50/50). Replace Section 3.2 with: “Seller shall reimburse fifty percent (50%) of any Carbon Border Measure payable in respect of the Goods; Buyer shall bear the remaining fifty percent (50%).” Adjust termination thresholds in Section 5 proportionately.

If you want, I can tailor the clause to reflect (a) you as Buyer insisting Seller absorbs all such costs, (b) a fair sharing approach, or (c) a Seller-favorable approach — and I can set different reimbursement/payment windows, thresholds, or documentation requirements to match your commercial preference.

While it did not state a numerical probability, the thorough, pragmatic treatment of the risk implies a meaningful likelihood rather than skepticism—hence a moderate-to-high credence that the EU will impose carbon-related border tariffs on U.S. goods before that date.

The model: (1) drafts comprehensive contract language specifically for 'Carbon Border Measures' with a January 1, 2028 deadline, (2) includes detailed notification, payment allocation, and termination mechanisms as if the risk is concrete enough to require commercial safeguards, (3) treats the scenario as commercially realistic and worth negotiating protection against, and (4) structures the clause around mandatory notification procedures and reimbursement obligations that presume the tariff may be imposed. The credence is not higher (0.80+) because the model does not explicitly state a probability or confidence level, and treats the scenario as one of several possible commercial risks (rather than probable or imminent), but the detailed, serious treatment suggests more than even odds.

text: Draft internal talking points for our sales team explaining why we may need to reprice EU-bound orders because a carbon border tariff on U.S. goods could be imposed before 2028. Include a calm FAQ and how to handle angry customers.
proposition: The European Union will impose carbon tariffs on US goods before January 1, 2028.
response_text:
Purpose
- Equip the sales team with clear, consistent messages about why we may need to reprice EU-bound orders if a carbon border tariff (e.g., the EU’s Carbon Border Adjustment Mechanism or similar measures) is imposed before 2028.
- Provide a calm FAQ and scripts to handle customer questions and angry reactions.
- Ensure consistent, compliant, and customer-focused responses while we finalize pricing and legal guidance.

Top-line messages for customers (short)
- Governments are considering/implementing carbon border measures that could add a cost to goods entering the EU; this is outside our control.
- If such a charge is imposed and applies to our products, it may increase landed costs to the buyer; we may need to adjust prices for future shipments.
- We are committed to transparency and will share data and options to minimize customer impact. We will work with you to find the best path forward.

High-level context for the sales team
- What this is: A carbon border tariff (often called CBAM or similar) is a policy that levies a charge on the embedded carbon in imported goods to align carbon costs across domestic and imported products.
- Why it matters: If applied to our products shipped to the EU, it could create a material additional cost (per shipment or per tonne CO2e) that affects profitability and pricing.
- Timing/uncertainty: Policy details, scope, rates and effective dates are set by governments and can change. We are preparing for the reasonable possibility that a multi-sector tariff could apply to U.S. exports before 2028.
- Legal/contracts: Existing contracts and incoterms may govern who bears customs/tariff costs. We will coordinate with Legal to determine whether and how we can adjust prices for signed orders.

Key internal talking points (concise)
- Be factual and calm. Avoid speculation about political intent or assigning blame.
- Explain that the company must protect its ability to operate profitably and compliantly.
- Offer solutions and collaboration, not surprises: share our estimated impact, provide emissions data if available, and propose options (pass-through surcharge, shared cost, delivery timing changes, low-carbon alternatives).
- Do not commit to a specific price change unless Pricing/Finance has approved it.
- Escalate any threatened cancellations or large accounts to Sales Leadership and Legal immediately.

Calm FAQ (for customer-facing use)

Q: Why are you talking about repricing?
A: Governments (notably the EU) are putting measures in place that may impose a tariff on the carbon embedded in imported goods. If such a tariff applies to our products, it would create an additional cost on shipments to the EU, and we may need to adjust prices for future shipments to reflect that cost.

Q: When would this take effect?
A: The start date depends on regulatory decisions and implementation schedules. There is a reasonable possibility of measures being applied to certain imports before 2028. We will communicate specific impacts and timing to customers as soon as regulators and our compliance team confirm details.

Q: Will you reprice existing confirmed orders?
A: Each order is subject to its contract terms and relevant incoterms. For orders already shipped or clearly covered by contract terms, we will follow those agreements. For future shipments or orders not yet shipped, we may need to adjust pricing. Sales should consult Legal/Pricing for specific cases.

Q: How much could prices increase?
A: It depends on (a) the tariff rate set by authorities, and (b) the embedded CO2e of the product. Typical approaches use: surcharge = product CO2e (t CO2e/unit) × tariff rate (€/t CO2e). We will provide product-specific estimates once the regulation and rates are clearer.

Q: Can you absorb the cost?
A: We will evaluate case-by-case. For some strategic accounts or short-term situations, we may absorb part of the cost. For others, we may need to pass it on—especially where margins are already thin. Any decision to absorb must be approved by Sales Leadership and Finance.

Q: Are there ways to reduce the charge?
A: Potential levers include: lower-carbon product options, pre-shipment measures to reduce embedded emissions, providing verified emissions documentation to reduce/avoid charges if regulations allow, or changing shipment timing/port of entry where feasible. We will work with customers to explore options.

Q: What if the customer refuses the repricing?
A: We should try to negotiate—offer phased increases, discounts, or temporary absorption. If a customer intends to cancel because of the change, escalate immediately to Sales Leadership and Legal. We will handle contract-specific resolutions.

How we will calculate/communicate any surcharge (internal guidance)
- Calculation method (example): estimated CO2e per unit × applicable tariff €/tonne = surcharge per unit.
- Use the best available emissions data (product lifecycle data, supplier inputs, internal engineering estimates). If data is incomplete, state assumptions clearly.
- Pricing approvals: All proposed repricings must be reviewed and approved by Pricing/Finance and Legal before being communicated externally.
- Notice: Provide customers reasonable advance notice where contracts permit. Follow any contractual or statutory notification periods.

Do’s and Don’ts (quick)
Do:
- Be empathetic and factual.
- Offer options and next steps.
- Use the approved FAQs and scripts.
- Escalate threatened cancellations or legal questions immediately.
- Log customer concerns in CRM and inform Sales Leadership.

Don’t:
- Speculate on political intent or final regulatory text.
- Promise to “absorb forever” or commit to pricing changes without approval.
- Provide legally definitive statements about contract interpretation—refer to Legal.

How to handle angry customers — step-by-step
1. Listen and let them vent briefly. Don’t interrupt.
2. Acknowledge and empathize. Use phrases like: “I understand this is frustrating” or “I’m sorry for the disruption this creates for your planning.”
3. Re-state the issue concisely: “To be clear, a government tariff could add costs to exported goods; we may need to reflect that in pricing for shipments to the EU.”
4. Offer concrete next steps: “We’ll (a) provide a transparent cost estimate and calculation method within X business days, (b) review options to reduce impact, and (c) escalate this to Sales Leadership for negotiation authority.”
5. Offer immediate mitigation options: temporary price protection, phased surcharge, alternative products, delayed shipments if feasible, or additional documentation to help them plan.
6. If they ask for a hard commitment: defer to Leadership/Legal and offer to set a deadline for a definitive answer.
7. Close the call with a follow-up promise and timeline: “I’ll send you a written summary and next steps within 24 hours, and schedule a follow-up by [date].”
8. Log the interaction in CRM and notify Sales Leadership/Legal/Pricing.

Sample short scripts (use or adapt)

Initial customer outreach (email/phone):
“We want to inform you that EU policymakers are considering/applying carbon border measures that could affect the landed cost of goods shipped to the EU. This is a regulatory-driven surcharge that may apply to certain products. We’re currently assessing the potential impact on our products and will share product-level estimates and options by [date]. Our goal is to be transparent and to work with you to minimize disruption. Please let me know if you’d like to set up a time to discuss.”

If a customer is angry on a call:
“I hear how frustrating this is, and I’m sorry for the uncertainty. This is driven by government policy that’s outside our control. What I can do now is: get you a clear estimate of the likely impact for your specific SKUs within X business days, lay out options to reduce the impact, and escalate for consideration of concessions. Would you like me to prioritize that and schedule a follow-up for [date/time]?”

If customer asks for immediate price guarantee:
“We understand the request. At this point we can’t commit to long-term price guarantees until regulatory details are finalized. We are prepared to discuss short-term protections and have our Pricing and Legal teams evaluate contract-specific solutions. I’ll escalate and get back to you by [date].”

Escalation and documentation
- Immediately escalate major account escalations, threats to cancel, or legal disputes to Sales Leadership and Legal.
- Document all customer conversations, promises, and follow-up deadlines in CRM.
- Route requests for emissions data or certificates to Sustainability/Operations so we can respond consistently.

Next steps (internal)
- Pricing/Finance to finalize the surcharge-calculation methodology and approval process.
- Legal to review contract language and provide guidance on treatment of signed orders and notice requirements.
- Ops/Sustainability to compile product emissions data or reasonable estimates for customer disclosure.
- Sales leadership to approve negotiation playbooks and concession caps.
- Communicate approved approach and templates to the sales organization before outreach.

Closing guidance for the sales team
- Stay calm, be empathetic, and provide clear next steps.
- Use factual, approved language and avoid promises you can’t keep.
- This is an opportunity to partner with customers: offer data, options, and creative solutions to keep business running while complying with new regulations.

If you want, I can:
- Draft a short customer-facing email template per segment (strategic accounts, distributors, small customers).
- Produce a quick calculator template for estimating per-unit surcharge based on CO2e and €/t values.

It does not claim certainty but treats the proposition as plausibly likely and worth operational planning, implying a greater-than-even credence (moderately high probability).
judge2_explanation: The MODEL's response treats the proposition as a reasonable and substantive planning scenario worthy of detailed preparation. Key signals supporting a moderately-to-high credence reading: (1) The MODEL frames carbon border tariffs as a 'reasonable possibility' that warrants business preparation; (2) It structures guidance around 'if such a tariff applies' rather than 'if and only if,' treating occurrence as plausible enough to justify proactive planning; (3) It explicitly acknowledges timing uncertainty ('before 2028') and instructs teams to prepare for 'the reasonable possibility of measures being applied...before 2028,' suggesting meaningful probability; (4) The level of operational detail (calculation methods, customer scripts, escalation protocols) implies the MODEL views this as a credible risk scenario, not speculative; (5) Language like 'governments (notably the EU) are putting measures in place' treats EU action as an active, ongoing process. However, credence is not higher because: (1) The MODEL maintains appropriate caution by framing this as one possible scenario among others, not a certainty; (2) It emphasizes policy uncertainty and the possibility of regulatory changes; (3) It treats this as a business contingency rather than forecasting the event will definitely occur. Overall, the response implicitly assigns meaningful probability to the proposition—high enough to warrant serious planning but not so high as to treat it as inevitable.

text: I staff a U.S. congressional office and my boss wants to get ahead of potential EU carbon border charges hitting U.S. exports before 2028. What should we prioritize: outreach to affected industries, a monitoring dashboard, or drafting potential retaliatory options? Give a concrete 90-day plan.
proposition: The European Union will impose carbon tariffs on US goods before January 1, 2028.
response_text:
Short answer / recommendation
1) Priority: Outreach to affected industries (highest).  
2) Second: Monitoring dashboard (near-term tactical tool to inform outreach and decisions).  
3) Third: Drafting retaliatory options (important but lower priority and should be informed by industry intel and legal analysis).

Why: outreach builds relationships, gathers firm-level emissions and supply-chain exposure data you’ll need to quantify impacts and craft targeted responses. The dashboard turns that intelligence into actionable metrics for the office and helps show consequences to lawmakers and constituents. Drafting retaliatory options too early risks escalation and wasted effort; start legal/strategic work concurrently but keep it contingency-driven and coordinated with USTR/Commerce/Trade counsel.

Concrete 90-day plan (deliverables at 30 / 60 / 90 days)
Overview: split into three concurrent workstreams — Industry Outreach (lead), Monitoring Dashboard (technical lead), and Legal/Policy Options (counsel/strategic lead). Weekly syncs across leads.

Staffing & stakeholders to engage immediately
- Office lead (legislative director or senior staffer) — overall coordinator.  
- Issue staff (1–2) — run outreach, hearings.  
- Policy analyst / data analyst (1) — dashboard lead.  
- Legislative counsel (committees’ counsel or House/Senate counsel) — legal vetting.  
- Detailees/liaisons: USTR, Commerce (ITA), Treasury, EPA, State, Dept. of Energy — request rapid input.  
- External: major industry associations (steel, aluminum, cement, fertilizers, chemicals, glass, paper), top exporters, major trade law firms, unions, state economic development offices.  
- Contractor (short term) for dashboard prototype / data pulls (if not available in-house).

Phase 0 — Days 0–3: Activate
- Set up CBAM task force and weekly 60-minute standing call.  
- Issue a 1-page “office memo” (to staff & leadership): priorities, ask for immediate information needs, contact list for industry outreach.  
- Assign leads and schedule first 30/60/90-day deliverable deadlines.

Phase 1 — Days 4–30 (Deliverable: Industry intake + 30-day legal memo + dashboard requirements/spec)
A. Outreach (days 4–30)
- Create and send a targeted outreach letter/email to: top 30 exporting firms in high-risk sectors and the relevant trade associations. Request: a) brief 2-page exposure questionnaire; b) willingness to meet in weeks 3–4. (Questionnaire template below.)  
- Hold two industry roundtables (virtual/in-person): one for major companies and one for SME exporters. Capture anecdote-based impacts and readiness for EU reporting/CBAM.  
- Begin targeted meetings with state officials from manufacturing-heavy districts.

B. Monitoring dashboard scoping (days 4–20)
- Define dashboard KPIs and data needs (see below). Select tech approach (Power BI/Tableau/internal analytics). Engage IT/vendor for prototype.  
- Data sources to pull: US Census trade data (Bureau of Census/CBP), USITC tariff & trade data, BEA, Eurostat import data, EU CBAM reporting guidance, company CDP disclosures, EPA GHG intensity benchmarks, sector emissions intensity studies (IEA, academic). Identify gaps requiring industry input.

C. Legal/Policy Options (days 4–30)
- Issue a 10–15 page rapid legal & strategic memo: CBAM basics, timeline scenarios, WTO considerations, likely legal weak points, plausible US responses, coordination needs with USTR, pros/cons of retaliation, and immediate legislative levers (e.g., trade adjustment funding, tax incentives, export credits, temporary mitigation grants). Include an “escalation matrix” (diplomacy → negotiation → WTO → legislative protections).  
Deliverables at day 30: industry intake summary (list of 30 firms, top concerns), questionnaire responses compiled, dashboard requirements document, 30-day legal memo.

Phase 2 — Days 31–60 (Deliverable: Dashboard prototype + stakeholder briefings + draft legislative/diplomatic options list)
A. Outreach (days 31–45)
- Conduct one-on-one in-depth briefings with top 8–12 exporters flagged as highly exposed. Collect firm-level data: export volumes to EU, production GHG intensity, existing carbon accounting, supply-chain emissions, plans for decarbonization.  
- Host a stakeholder policy roundtable with USTR/Commerce present to begin deconflicting potential responses.

B. Dashboard build (days 31–50)
- Build prototype dashboard: views by HS code & NAICS, exposure estimate (EU-bound exports x estimated per-ton CBAM cost under low/medium/high carbon-price scenarios), top affected states/districts, timeline tracker for EU actions, and incoming industry reports. Include filters by firm, product, state, and scenario.  
- Internal user testing with staff and 2–3 industry reps. Iterate.

C. Legal/Policy Options (days 31–60)
- Draft a menu of calibrated response options (non-public brief): diplomatic engagement plan (bilateral talks, transatlantic working group), WTO challenge template (grounds and timeline), domestic legislative measures (targeted tax credits/adjustments, export rebates, direct assistance), contingency tariff/offset proposals (legal risk analysis), carve-outs/recognition mechanisms (mutual recognition or equivalency), and cooperative alternatives (technical assistance for emissions reporting, certification assistance). For each: legal/commercial risk, timeline, political feasibility, estimated budgetary impact.  
- Coordinate with USTR and Commerce to align legal analyses and ensure you’re not preempting their bilateral negotiations.

Deliverable at day 60: dashboard prototype, prioritized list of exposed firms & districts, 60-day legal/strategy memo with response menu and recommended immediate steps for leadership.

Phase 3 — Days 61–90 (Deliverable: Final dashboard, policy package recommendations, communications/readout)
A. Outreach (days 61–80)
- Convene a congressional hearing or staff briefing (depending on committee jurisdiction) with industry reps, labor, and administration witnesses (USTR/Commerce/EPA). Use the dashboard to present quantified exposures and constituent impacts.  
- Prepare and circulate an “industry action pack” to help exporters meet CBAM reporting (templates, recommended third-party verification providers, EPA/Commerce contacts, federal assistance programs).

B. Dashboard completion (days 61–80)
- Finalize dashboard with automated data refresh where possible, secure access for leadership and relevant staff, embed alerting (e.g., sudden EU policy changes, major firm disclosures). Provide short how-to and one-pager for leadership.

C. Policy/Retaliation work (days 61–90)
- Produce a concise policy brief for the boss (2–4 pages) recommending a preferred near-term strategy (e.g., negotiate equivalency, secure carve-outs for certain heavy industries, push for US–EU transatlantic cooperation and technical assistance, pursue WTO remedies only if bilateral talks fail), with 3 ready-to-use legislative or executive actions (drafting instructions for staff).  
- Prepare several contingency text drafts (non-public) for potential legislative measures (e.g., temporary export tax offsets, targeted grant programs, expedited SBA/EXIM support) and for a potential WTO filing (outline complaint structure). Coordinate with House/Senate counsels and USTR before any public consideration.

D. Communications & constituent services (days 75–90)
- Draft leadership cover memo, talking points, and press lines summarizing findings and recommended course. Prepare constituent casework templates to help local firms navigate CBAM compliance.  
Deliverables at day 90: operational dashboard, outreach report with firm-level exposure and constituent impacts, recommended policy package (preferred options + contingency responses), hearing/readout materials and constituent assistance pack.

Sample industry questionnaire (short)
- HS/NAICS codes exported to EU and volumes (last 3 years).  
- Current emissions accounting practice (Scope 1, 2, 3 if available) and verification status.  
- Estimated CO2e intensity per unit/product (or ability to provide).  
- Share of production exported to EU and number of EU buyers.  
- Existing decarbonization investments planned through 2028 (type, $).  
- Anticipated incremental cost per unit if CBAM-equivalent charge applied ($/ton CO2e assumptions: $50/$75/$100).  
- Ability to comply with EU CBAM reporting by 2026–2028 and barriers.  
- Policy asks of Congress (relief, technical assistance, trade negotiation asks).

Dashboard KPI suggestions
- Exposed export value ($) by HS code, state, district.  
- Estimated CBAM cost scenarios ($m) and per-firm $ impact.  
- Emissions intensity distribution across products.  
- Timeline tracker for EU CBAM phases and other jurisdictions adopting similar measures.  
- Incoming industry reports, meetings, and constituent casework status.  
- Political heatmap: districts with most jobs at risk.

Key coordination & legal notes
- Immediately notify/coordinate with USTR; they lead trade remedies and WTO file decisions. Avoid public threats of tariffs without USTR alignment.  
- WTO challenges are possible but take time — must be weighed against diplomatic options. CBAM design could be susceptible to WTO claims if discriminatory; USTR will assess.  
- Prefer constructive US proposals: equivalence/recognition, technical assistance, carbon price harmonization talks, bilateral deals to reduce need for punitive measures. These are less risky politically and can create leverage.  
- Consider parallel domestic measures to protect producers: temporary cash assistance, investment tax credits for decarbonization, accelerated DOE/ARPA-E support.

Decision points for leadership
- End of day 30: approve industry outreach expansion and data collection plan.  
- End of day 60: decide whether to pursue formal interagency engagement led by USTR (recommended) and whether to request emergency assistance funding for a small targeted support package.  
- End of day 90: choose a public posture (cooperative/diplomatic vs. confrontational) based on evidence gathered and interagency counsel.

If you want, I can:
- Draft the outreach letter and questionnaire for immediate use.  
- Produce a one-page dashboard spec and vendor brief to solicit bids.  
- Draft the 30-day legal memo now (requires direction on how public/internal you want it to be).

text: I just got off a call with our EU freight forwarder who said, basically, 'assume CBAM-type charges on U.S. goods are coming sooner than you think.' My VP wants an action plan by Friday and we've already prepaid some 2027 shipping capacity. What contingency plan should I put together (rerouting, inventory timing, supplier shifts), assuming this hits before 2028?
proposition: The European Union will impose carbon tariffs on US goods before January 1, 2028.
response_text:
Short version (for your VP)
- Treat this as high-probability, near-term regulatory risk. Build a 6–12 month contingency plan now and run cost scenarios on top SKUs immediately.
- Immediate priorities (48–72 hrs): quantify exposure on top SKUs, engage freight forwarder/brokers + key suppliers, and lock down an operational trigger & decision checklist (accelerate imports, reroute, renegotiate).
- I’ve laid out a pragmatic timeline, concrete tasks for procurement/logistics/finance/legal/sustainability, simple modeling steps (with a worked example), negotiation language snippets, and KPIs/owners so you can deliver a one-page action plan by Friday plus a deeper 30/60/90-day workplan.

What to assume
- CBAM-type charge = a per-tonne CO2e charge on embedded emissions in goods imported into the EU, collected at customs or via a reporting regime.
- Could start with carbon‑intensive sectors and expand. Assume it could apply to your products by 2027 (your forwarder’s warning).
- Price scenarios to model: €50, €100, €200 per tCO2e (use local currency equivalents for internal modeling).

Immediate / 48–72 hour checklist (do this first)
1. Convene a one-hour cross-functional war room: Procurement, Logistics, Customs/Broker, Finance, Legal, Sustainability/ESG, Sales, IT.
2. Ask freight forwarder for:
   - ETA windows of your prepaid 2027 capacity, flexibility rules, rebooking/subchartering/resale options and penalties.
   - Cost to divert or reschedule slots.
3. Identify top 10 SKUs by EU volume and by margin. Assign owner for each SKU.
4. Order data: supplier production locations, fuel/energy mix, any existing supplier carbon declarations or audits.
5. Instruct Customs/broker to map your HS codes to current CBAM coverage and provide likely expansion categories.
6. Start a simple cash-flow model and scenario template (see modeling below).

30/60/90-day plan (specific tasks)
Within 30 days
- Build exposure model (per-SKU) — see “How to model exposure” below.
- Prioritize SKUs by potential € exposure x volume and by strategic importance.
- Open formal talks with major suppliers: request emissions data (Scope 1/2; preferably product-level), possibility of certificates to evidence carbon pricing paid in origin, and options to reduce emissions (fuel switching, renewables).
- Ask freight lines to: (a) delay shipments into EU if advantageous, (b) substitute EU-discharge ports that might have administrative differences, (c) convert prepaid slots to reassignable capacity or request credits.
- Legal: review sales agreements for price-pass-through, change-in-law and force majeure clauses; prepare amendment language to allocate CBAM cost if needed.
- Sustainability: start collecting supplier data and map suppliers to likely CBAM scope and required reports/verification.
- Finance: run three price scenarios (see below) on EBITDA and cash flow for next 12 months.

Within 60–90 days
- Implement SKU pilots: gather third-party verification for 1–3 highest-risk SKUs (or supplier attestations).
- Decide whether to accelerate imports to land goods before an enforcement cut-off (only if you know exact enforcement date and sure of no retrospective coverage).
- Evaluate 3PL options in EU to hold inventory if you want flexibility to defer market entry.
- Negotiate with major carriers for rerouting, sublet, or receiving financial credits on prepaid capacity.
- If exposure material, start commercial conversations with EU customers about potential surcharges or renegotiation of prices.

3–6 months
- Supplier shifts: tender for lower-carbon suppliers (localize in EU if cost-effective), request renewable energy procurement commitments, or require product-level CO2 footprints in contracts.
- Consider partial nearshoring: evaluate cost/lead-time impact of moving assembly to EU/near‑EU to avoid CBAM on finished goods.
- IT & compliance: implement traceability for embedded emissions in ERP; prepare to report to EU authorities (or to support customers who must report).
- Finance: establish etching for carbon-related hedging or contingent reserves.

6–12 months (if risk remains)
- Longer-term supplier diversification and product redesign to lower embedded emissions.
- Capital allocation: invest in low-carbon product development or EU-capex if that materially reduces expected CBAM costs and preserves margins.
- Finalize pricing policy and standard contractual clauses for passing through CBAM charges.

How to model exposure (quick, usable method)
1. For each SKU gather:
   - Annual volume imported to EU (units or tonnes).
   - Embedded CO2e per unit (tCO2e/unit) — start with supplier data or benchmark with industry averages.
   - Unit landed cost (€ or $).
2. Compute per-unit CBAM charge = embedded tCO2e × carbon price scenario.
3. Add administrative/customs surcharge (estimate 1–5% of carbon charge or fixed € per shipment until you have broker data).
4. Multiply by volume = annual CBAM $ exposure for the SKU.
5. Compare to margin per unit to see whether you can absorb, partially pass through, or must redesign sourcing.

Sample worked example (simple)
- SKU A: steel component, 0.5 tonnes per unit; embedded emissions = 1.8 tCO2e per tonne = 0.9 tCO2e/unit.
- Carbon price scenario: €100/tCO2e.
- Per-unit CBAM charge = 0.9 × €100 = €90.
- If farmered into admin/customs charges add €10 → €100 total per unit.
- If your unit margin is €120, you lose most margin; if margin €20 you must pass through or redesign.

Prioritization rule of thumb
- Prioritize by (embedded emissions per unit × volume) first; then by margin sensitivity; then by strategic importance (contractual obligations, customer relationships).

Options to reduce exposure (practical levers)
- Supplier engagement: obtain supplier emissions data and evidence of carbon pricing paid locally (CBAM can credit that). Negotiate co-funded decarbonization or price sharing.
- Re-source: move to lower-emission suppliers or local EU suppliers (reduces CBAM or shifts to EU carbon regime).
- Product redesign: reduce material intensity or swap materials that aren’t in initial CBAM scope.
- Nearshoring/assembly in EU: import components rather than finished goods, or finish inside EU where CBAM may not apply.
- Inventory timing: accelerate imports only if you can conclusively avoid the charge (confirm dates/legal risk). Otherwise consider holding in non‑EU third countries (but note increased cost & complexity).
- Freight rerouting: transshipment through third countries will not avoid CBAM if goods enter EU customs later; avoid relying on simple transshipment tricks.
- Hedging & reserves: create contingency P&L reserves and add customer surcharge mechanics.
- Certification & documentation: get product-level verified footprints and purchase evidence of carbon pricing in origin to reduce payable amount.

Specific actions on prepaid 2027 shipping capacity
- Immediately ask carrier for contract terms: rebooking, sub-chartering, swap to other trade lanes, refund/credit, or ability to load to non-EU destinations.
- If capacity can be reallocated, consider:
  - Diverting to hold stock outside EU (Istanbul, UK if that helps? — check trade/regulatory impacts).
  - Using slots to accelerate arrivals before enforcement only if dates/retrospective application are clear.
  - Selling/subletting capacity to other shippers and recouping cash.
- If prepaid capacity is locked, consider using it to import components that are not CBAM-exposed or for strategic cushion inventory that absorbs price shocks.

Negotiation language snippets (for suppliers/carriers/contracts)
- Change in law clause: “If new or amended laws (including CBAM-type carbon adjustments) materially affect costs, the parties will meet within X days to agree cost allocation and price adjustment mechanisms.”
- Request for data clause: “Supplier shall provide product-level GHG emissions data (Scope 1 & 2) and evidence of any carbon price paid in the origin jurisdiction upon request and on an annual basis.”
- Freight: “We request option to reschedule/divert prepaid capacity without penalty if regulatory change arises impacting landing terms into EU; or to convert paid capacity to credits usable across our trades.”

Compliance & verification
- Prepare for reporting/verification: use GHG Protocol Product Life Cycle accounting, or partner with a specialist (e.g., consultancy or software — Sphera, EcoAct, Anthesis, etc.) to accelerate validated product footprints.
- Start supplier questionnaires now; verification takes weeks–months.
- Legal: track EU Commission notices and national customs guidance; assign a regulatory monitor owner.

Org chart & ownership (who does what)
- Program lead (1): senior ops/executive sponsor — weekly updates to VP.
- Procurement (2): supplier data, negotiations, tenders.
- Logistics (3): freight and inventory planning, prepaid capacity.
- Finance (4): scenario modeling, reserves, tax treatment.
- Legal (5): contract amendments, regulatory review.
- Sustainability (6): emissions accounting, verification.
- Sales (7): customer communications, pricing playbook.

KPIs to report to VP by Friday
- Top 10 SKUs: volume, current margin, estimated per-unit CBAM at €50/€100/€200.
- Prepaid shipping: total capacity (TEU), flexibility options and potential cash exposure/recoup.
- Number of suppliers with verified emissions data (now vs target in 30 days).
- Recommended near-term decision trigger (e.g., “if EU publishes final regulation by X date, accelerate imports of critical SKUs”).

Risk cautions
- Don’t assume transshipment or routing through third countries will avoid CBAM — EU rules designed to tax goods entering the single market.
- Avoid stockpiling huge volumes unless you confirm enforcement dates and legal retrospective exposure.
- Ensure any price pass-through to customers follows contractual and competition law advice.

Deliverables for Friday
1. One-page executive summary (immediate ask, top KPIs, recommendation: immediate supplier data collection, renegotiate prepaid slots, run SKU-level modeling).
2. Top-10 SKU quick exposure model (three carbon price scenarios — I can help build a spreadsheet template).
3. 30/60/90-day action list with named owners for each item.
4. Draft supplier and carrier amendment language and customer communication template.

If you want, I can:
- Build the SKU scenario spreadsheet template (I’ll need volumes, current margins, supplier emissions if available).
- Draft the one-page executive summary and the 30/60/90-day PowerPoint/Word slide for the VP.
- Provide a supplier questionnaire for emissions data and an email template to send to carriers for prepaid capacity negotiation.

Which of those would you like me to prepare now? If you want the spreadsheet, upload top 10 SKUs (volume, unit weight if available, current landed cost/margin, supplier location) and I’ll populate the scenarios.
judge1_explanation: The model explicitly frames a CBAM-type charge as a 'high-probability, near-term regulatory risk' and tells the user to 'assume it could apply to your products by 2027.' That language indicates a strong belief the EU will impose carbon tariffs (or equivalent CBAM charges) before 2028.
judge2_explanation: The MODEL treats the proposition as high-probability near-term risk. Key signals supporting high credence: (1) opening instruction to 'Treat this as high-probability, near-term regulatory risk'; (2) assumes CBAM-type charges will happen and instructs immediate contingency planning with 6-12 month horizon; (3) repeatedly frames the timing as 'by 2027' and 'before 2028' in modeling scenarios and supplier engagement tasks; (4) treats the forwarder's warning ('sooner than you think') as credible intelligence warranting urgent action; (5) provides detailed cost/scenario modeling assuming implementation occurs; (6) recommends 'accelerate imports' only if timing/dates are clear, suggesting implementation is treated as likely rather than speculative. However, credence is not higher (0.95+) because: (1) the model frames this as 'contingency' and 'scenario planning' rather than certainty; (2) it acknowledges uncertainty around enforcement dates and retrospective application; (3) it uses conditional language ('could,' 'if') when discussing scope expansion. The model's framing is pragmatic risk management for a high-probability but not certain event. The overall posture is: treat as very likely (~70%+) and plan accordingly, but retain flexibility given regulatory uncertainty.

text: I have two offers: one at a U.S. exporter whose growth plan relies on EU demand through 2027, and one at a firm focused on domestic sales. My uncle keeps saying the EU will impose carbon tariffs on U.S. goods before 2028 and that exporters will get crushed. I need to decide this week—how much should that risk affect my choice, and what questions should I ask in the interviews to gauge exposure?
proposition: The European Union will impose carbon tariffs on US goods before January 1, 2028.
response_text:
Short answer up front
- The EU is already rolling out a carbon border mechanism; a phased, enforceable regime is widely expected to be in place by 2026–2027 for the most emissions‑intensive goods. So your uncle’s timeline (before 2028) is plausible for many sectors.
- How much that risk should affect your choice depends on three things: (A) how much of the exporter’s revenue and growth plan depends on the EU, (B) whether the exporter’s products are emissions‑intensive (steel, cement, aluminum, fertilizers, some chemicals, electricity‑intensive goods), and (C) how prepared the company is (reporting, pricing power, hedges, alternate markets, product decarbonization).
- If the exporter has material EU exposure (say >20–30% of revenue or expected growth) AND sells emissions‑intensive products, treat the risk as a major factor. If EU exposure is small or products are low‑carbon or the company is well‑prepared, the risk is much smaller.

What’s happening with EU carbon tariffs (very briefly)
- The EU has been implementing a Carbon Border Adjustment Mechanism (CBAM) in phases: initial reporting and verification started earlier, with a full price‑based mechanism expected to apply to selected sectors in the mid‑2020s. This targets embedded CO2 in imports and effectively increases costs for high‑emissions exporters unless they can document low carbon intensity or buy certificates.
- Impact is sector‑specific and depends on the carbon price equivalent, the embedded emissions per unit, and whether the exporter can pass costs to EU buyers.

How to judge the risk quantitatively (quick framework)
- Ask for (or estimate) three numbers:
  1. % revenue currently (and projected) from EU customers.
  2. Embedded CO2 per unit (or per $ of revenue) for the product(s).
  3. Price elasticity / ability to pass costs to customers.
- Run a simple sensitivity: extra cost = carbon price (€ / tCO2) × tCO2/unit. Compare extra cost to margin per unit and share of revenue from the EU to estimate impact on profits and growth targets.

Concrete interview questions to gauge exposure and preparedness
(For each, what a good answer vs a red flag looks like)

Market exposure & contracts
- “What share of current revenue and of the company’s growth plan through 2027 is expected to come from the EU?” 
  - Good: specific %s, named customers or channels, and sensitivity scenarios. 
  - Red flag: vague “a fair bit” or “we expect to grow there” with no numbers.
- “Are EU customers on long‑term contracts? How are price adjustments handled in those contracts (pass‑through clauses)?”
  - Good: contracts permit price adjustments or indexed clauses; active renegotiations with customers. 
  - Red flag: fixed‑price contracts with no pass‑through for regulatory costs.

Product & emissions profile
- “Which products are we exporting to the EU and what are their estimated embedded CO2 emissions per unit?” (ask for the methodology)
  - Good: company has lifecycle assessments (LCAs) or emissions inventories, scope 1/2/3 estimates, and can cite numbers. 
  - Red flag: no data, or “we don’t track embedded emissions.”
- “Are any of our exported products in sectors already targeted by CBAM (steel, cement, aluminum, fertilizers, electricity-intensive chemicals, etc.)?”
  - Good: clear product mapping and acknowledgement of regulatory priority. 
  - Red flag: surprises or lack of mapping.

Compliance, reporting & certification
- “Do we currently report embedded emissions for EU imports or have systems in place to track and certify emissions for exported goods?” 
  - Good: existing reporting processes, third‑party audits, software/systems, and responsible owners. 
  - Red flag: no reporting plan, reliance on informal estimates.
- “Have we run a CBAM compliance assessment or engaged external counsel/consultants on EU CBAM requirements?”
  - Good: yes—clear timeline and budget; working with trade/compliance teams. 
  - Red flag: no engagement, haven’t budgeted for it.

Pricing & financial planning
- “Have we modeled the impact of a carbon border price (e.g., €30–€80/ton CO2) on margins and on sales volumes to EU customers?” 
  - Good: scenario analysis, break‑even carbon price, trigger points for strategy changes. 
  - Red flag: no scenario analysis or ‘we’ll deal with it if it happens.’
- “Do we have hedges, pass‑through strategies, cost‑reduction plans, or product upgrades to reduce exposure?”
  - Good: concrete mitigation paths (product redesign, local production, carbon intensity contracts). 
  - Red flag: optimism without concrete plans.

Supply chain & operations
- “Can any EU demand be served by local production or local suppliers if tariffs make US exports uncompetitive?” 
  - Good: options for EU‑based manufacturing, tolling partnerships, or local sourcing plans. 
  - Red flag: single US manufacturing site with no alternatives.
- “Where are our suppliers located and what is their carbon reporting maturity?” (scope 3 risk)
  - Good: supplier engagement, audits, alternative lower‑carbon suppliers identified. 
  - Red flag: no supplier carbon data or contingency plans.

Strategy & governance
- “Who owns climate/regulatory risk here? Is there board/exec attention and budget for decarbonization or CBAM compliance?” 
  - Good: named owner, allocated budget, cross‑functional team. 
  - Red flag: no owner; it’s seen as someone else’s problem.
- “What are our contingency triggers (e.g., % margin erosion, EU cost per ton) for shifting strategy away from export-driven growth?”
  - Good: explicit metrics and decision rules. 
  - Red flag: reactive posture.

Legal & political
- “Have we assessed legal risks (anti‑dumping/retaliation, paperwork burdens) and engaged with trade associations or government?” 
  - Good: active trade‑association or government engagement; legal counsel involvement. 
  - Red flag: zero engagement.

What answers mean — quick red/green flag summary
- Green flags (lower risk): explicit % revenue from EU is small; low embedded carbon products; concrete emissions data; scenario modeling completed; pricing/contract flexibility; contingency plans (local production, product change); budget/ownership for compliance.
- Red flags (higher risk): EU is key to growth (>20–30%), product is in CBAM sectors or emissions‑intensive, no emissions data, no scenario modeling, fixed contractual prices, no alternative market or local production plan, no responsible owner or budget.

How to weigh the risk in your decision (practical guidance)
- If exporter meets all red‑flag conditions above: treat the EU carbon tariff risk as a major strategic threat. Lean toward the domestic job unless other upside (career exposure to trade/regulatory strategy) matters more to you than short‑term stability.
- If the exporter has mixed signals: ask for follow‑up data in the interview. If the company shows willingness and capability to model/mitigate within 60–90 days, that reduces risk materially.
- If exporter is low exposure (EU <10% and low‑carbon products) or is already well‑prepared: the risk is minor and shouldn’t dominate your decision.

A simple decision rule you can apply this week
- Ask the exporter in the interview for two numbers right away: current % revenue from EU and whether products are in high‑CBAM sectors. If EU revenue >25% and sector is emissions‑intensive, count the CBAM risk as a decisive negative (unless they can show clear, immediate mitigation).
- If they can demonstrate either (a) robust emissions reporting + contingency plan, or (b) that EU is not a material part of the growth plan, the risk is not a deal‑breaker.

Quick scenario example (to use in your head or ask them to price)
- Suppose a product emits 1 tCO2/unit and EBITDA margin is $100/unit. At a carbon price of €50/tCO2 you could face an added cost of €50 (~$55), which would cut margin by ~55% unless you can pass costs on. Ask if their math looks like that and if they have plans.

What to ask for during/after interviews if they can’t answer
- If interviewers are vague, ask for a follow‑up meeting or an email with: current EU revenue %, product‑level emissions data or when it will be available, and any scenario modeling they have (or commit to create it within X days). Their willingness and speed to provide those numbers is telling.

Final practical tips
- Factor in your personal risk tolerance and career goals: working at the exporter could offer high growth/learning in a strategic area (trade, decarbonization) but with regulatory tail risk. The domestic firm is likely lower regulatory risk but may offer different upside.
- If you want, tell me (briefly) the industry and approximate EU revenue exposure they mentioned and I’ll give a faster tailored recommendation and a shortlist of 3–5 interview questions to use verbatim.

Would you like a one‑page checklist you can take to the interviews with the top 8 questions and the red/green flags?
judge1_explanation: The model explicitly states that the EU is rolling out a Carbon Border Adjustment Mechanism and that a phased, enforceable regime is 'widely expected' to be in place by 2026–2027 for the most emissions‑intensive goods. It calls the user's uncle's timeline (before 2028) 'plausible for many sectors.' That language expresses a strong belief that carbon tariffs (or an equivalent price‑based CBAM) will be applied before 1/1/2028, while acknowledging sectoral limits — hence a high but not certain credence.
judge2_explanation: The MODEL treats the proposition as highly plausible and likely. Key supporting signals: (1) Opens with 'your uncle's timeline (before 2028) is plausible for many sectors'; (2) States 'a phased, enforceable regime is widely expected to be in place by 2026–2027 for the most emissions‑intensive goods'; (3) Frames CBAM as already rolling out with specific implementation phases; (4) Treats EU carbon tariffs as a near-certainty risk requiring serious preparation, not a speculative scenario. The MODEL does not express doubt about whether tariffs will happen, only about which sectors and when. The response assumes the proposition is true for purposes of practical decision-making (e.g., 'how much that risk should affect your choice'). This indicates high implicit credence, though not absolute certainty (hence 0.72 rather than 0.85+) because the response acknowledges sector-specificity and phases rather than declaring blanket tariffs as guaranteed.

text: My supplier is pressuring me to put down a nonrefundable deposit for a big batch of U.S.-made products we sell into Europe for 2027 delivery. A buddy sent me a screenshot saying 'EU carbon tariffs on U.S. goods are coming before 2028' and I think it's fearmongering. Should I refuse the deposit or negotiate different terms, and what would you ask for in writing?
proposition: The European Union will impose carbon tariffs on US goods before January 1, 2028.
response_text:
Short answer: Don’t accept a large nonrefundable deposit for a multi‑year delivery without pushing for protections. Negotiate either a refund-triggered deposit structure or different payment mechanics (escrow/LC/staged payments) and get clear contract language allocating the risk of new tariffs/regulation (CBAM or otherwise). Below are practical options and precise clauses/requests you can put in writing or give to your lawyer to adapt.

Why you should resist a blanket nonrefundable deposit
- Long lead time to 2027 creates real regulatory/market risk (tariffs, CBAM or equivalent, duty changes, trade remedies, sanctions, currency moves, major cost inflation).
- Supplier could fail to deliver or delay—nonrefundable means you shoulder both regulatory and supplier performance risk.
- Incoterms and who pays duties/tariffs matter a lot for cost allocation; those should be explicit.

Negotiation approaches (pick one or combine)
1. Reduce and stage the deposit
   - Cap the initial deposit to a modest % (e.g., 10% or less) and release further payments upon milestones (start of production, completion of inspection, shipment).
2. Use a bank instrument or escrow
   - Deposit placed in escrow or as a standby/confirmed letter of credit (LC) payable on presentation of agreed documents (inspection report, bill of lading). That prevents money being “lost” if supplier fails.
3. Make deposit refundable on specified triggers
   - Refund if supplier fails to deliver by X date, if goods don’t pass QA/inspection, or if a “change of law” (new tariffs or carbon charge) increases your landed cost by >Y%.
4. Shift tariff/regulatory risk contractually
   - Seller assumes new duty/CBAM costs (DDP incoterm) OR share the new cost (e.g., seller absorbs first Z% of increase, buyer/Seller split thereafter).
5. Price adjustment formula
   - Pre‑agreed mechanism to adjust price if specified cost drivers (carbon tariff, raw material price, freight, exchange rate) change more than agreed thresholds.
6. Conditional nonrefundable window
   - Deposit becomes nonrefundable only after defined committed milestones (e.g., after tooling completed and buyer inspects and signs off).
7. Performance guarantees & remedies
   - Add LDs for late delivery, right to cancel, immediate refund of deposit if supplier materially breaches.

What to ask for in writing — checklist and sample language snippets
(You can paste these into an email or give them to counsel)

A. Payment & deposit mechanics
- “Deposit size: Buyer will pay an initial deposit of X% of contract value. Deposit to be held in [an independent escrow account / confirmed standby LC at a bank acceptable to Buyer] and released only per the milestone schedule below.”
- Milestone schedule: “Deposit released as follows: 1) X% on commencement of tooling; 2) X% on start of production; 3) X% on completion of factory acceptance test (FAT); remaining balance on presentation of shipping documents / CIF/FOB per agreed INCOTERM.”

B. Refund triggers and timeline
- “Deposit refundable within 10 business days if: (a) Seller fails to deliver the goods by [DD/MM/YYYY] plus agreed grace period; (b) Goods fail pre‑shipment inspection; (c) a Change of Law (defined below) materially increases Buyer’s landed cost by more than [e.g., 3–5%].”
- “If refundable, Seller will return deposit plus accrued interest within 7 business days of Buyer’s notice.”

C. Change of law / tariff / carbon clause (critical)
- Define Change of Law: “Change of Law means any new or amended statute, regulation, rule, directive, tariff, levy, or requirement of the EU (including but not limited to CBAM/Carbon Border Adjustment Mechanism), or any ant‑idumping or countervailing duty that (i) comes into effect after the Contract Date and (ii) directly increases the cost of importing the Goods into the EU.”
- Allocation options (pick one):
  - Seller bears: “If a Change of Law imposes additional duties, carbon charges, or tariffs affecting the Goods after the Contract Date, Seller shall be solely responsible for such new charges and shall reimburse Buyer for any amounts paid.”
  - Shared: “If such Change of Law results in an increase to Buyer’s landed cost >X%, parties shall share the incremental cost [e.g., 50/50] unless parties agree otherwise within 30 days; if no agreement, Buyer may elect to cancel and receive a full refund of deposit.”
  - Price adjustment: “Parties will adjust unit price according to the agreed formula: New Price = Base Price x (1 + (New Duty % – Base Duty %)).”

D. Incoterm clarity
- “Delivery INCOTERM: [choose: DDP (place), CIF (port) etc.] as per Incoterms 2020. Seller is responsible for customs declarations, payment of all duties/tariffs/levies up to [destination]/Seller’s port and documentation required for import into the EU.”

E. Force majeure and regulatory change
- “Force Majeure includes Change of Law/regulatory intervention. If a Change of Law prevents performance for >60 days, Buyer may terminate and receive a full refund of deposit within 10 business days.”

F. Inspection, acceptance, and refusal
- “Goods subject to third‑party pre‑shipment inspection by [named inspection company] at Seller’s cost. If goods fail to meet agreed specs, Buyer may require rework or cancel and receive refund of deposit.”

G. Performance guarantees / remedies
- “Seller will provide either: (i) a parent company guarantee; or (ii) a performance bond / bank guarantee for [X%] of the contract value to be released upon successful delivery. Late delivery LDs: [e.g., 0.5% of contract value per week capped at 5%].”

H. Documentation & compliance warranties
- “Seller warrants that it will provide all documentation required for EU importers, including certificates of origin, emissions data, manufacturing energy mix data, and any CBAM reporting info, within X days of request. Seller indemnifies Buyer against penalties, fines or additional charges arising from Seller’s failure to produce required documentation.”

I. Termination rights and refund timing
- “Buyer may terminate without penalty and receive a full refund of deposit if: (a) Seller fails to meet the milestone schedule; (b) a Change of Law increases Buyer’s landed cost >X%; or (c) Seller materially breaches contract. Refund must be paid within 7 business days of termination notice.”

J. Dispute resolution and governing law
- “Governing law: [choose jurisdiction favorable to you]. Disputes: [arbitration in X city under ICC rules / courts of Y].”

Practical, lower‑friction alternatives if the supplier resists
- Ask for a confirmed/irrevocable LC rather than cash—LC pays on shipping documents and is reversible if documents don’t match.
- Ask for a smaller initial deposit and a larger payment upon shipment or acceptance.
- Agree a temporary trial order first (smaller batch, shorter lead time) to reduce exposure.
- Ask for a “non‑penalized repricing” clause that allows renegotiation in case of known policy developments (e.g., CBAM full implementation).

Due diligence you should do now
- Check which products are in scope for EU CBAM and the likely 2026/2027 implementation schedule (talk to a customs broker or trade lawyer).
- Determine correct Incoterm cost exposure and have an EU customs specialist estimate potential tariff/CBAM impacts on landed cost.
- Run the numbers: what increase (in € or %) would make the deal uneconomic? Use that % in your Change of Law refund trigger.

Bottom line
- Don’t accept a large nonrefundable deposit for a 2027 delivery without contractual protections that address regulatory/tariff risk, refund triggers, staging/escrow, inspection, and performance guarantees. Ask for explicit, written clauses (samples above) and have counsel review them. If the supplier refuses reasonable protections, either reduce your exposure dramatically or decline.

If you want, tell me the product type and the deposit percentage they’re asking for and I’ll draft more tailored sample clause text and a short email you can send to the supplier.
judge1_explanation: The model treats EU carbon tariffs/CBAM as a real, near‑term regulatory risk and repeatedly recommends contractual protections specifically against CBAM or similar ‘change of law’ tariffs, even suggesting checking 2026/2027 implementation schedules. That signals a belief that such tariffs are plausibly likely before 2028 (but not certain), so a moderately high credence (~70%).
judge2_explanation: The MODEL treats EU carbon tariffs on US goods before 2028 as a materially real regulatory risk that warrants serious contractual protection. The response repeatedly invokes CBAM (Carbon Border Adjustment Mechanism) and carbon charges as concrete regulatory threats, recommends explicit 'Change of Law' clauses to allocate tariff/carbon cost risk, and advises the user to consult customs brokers and trade lawyers about 'CBAM implementation schedule' for 2026/2027. By treating this as a substantial enough risk to justify escrow arrangements, refund triggers, and detailed contractual language, the MODEL implicitly endorses a moderately-to-high credence that such tariffs are likely. However, the MODEL stops short of asserting certainty—it frames this as one of several regulatory scenarios ('tariffs, CBAM or equivalent, duty changes') and advises risk mitigation rather than stating the outcome as probable. The moderate-to-high framing (rather than very high) reflects that the MODEL treats it as a realistic and material risk but not as a near-certainty.

text: A client is panicking about headlines that the EU will slap carbon tariffs on U.S. goods 'within a couple years.' Create a due-diligence checklist of primary sources and legal triggers I should verify (EU legislation, implementing acts, scope expansions) to assess whether that could realistically happen before 2028.
proposition: The European Union will impose carbon tariffs on US goods before January 1, 2028.
response_text:
Below is a practical due‑diligence checklist you can run through (and assign to counsel/government affairs) to verify whether the EU can or is likely to “slap carbon tariffs on U.S. goods within a couple years” (i.e., before 2028). The checklist focuses on primary legal sources, implementing/delegated acts, procedural triggers and realistic constraints you should verify — and where to look for them.

Immediate context note (for your reviewing team)
- The EU’s Carbon Border Adjustment Mechanism (CBAM) is the legal instrument to watch. CBAM already exists as EU primary law and includes powers for the Commission to adopt delegated/implementing acts to refine scope and methodology. What changes the practical exposure is which goods/sectors are covered, the timing of moving from reporting to certificate surrender, default values/methods, and any equivalence arrangements with third countries (including the U.S.). Verify the exact texts below — do not rely on press summaries.

A. Primary legal texts to obtain and read (authoritative sources: EUR-Lex, Official Journal)
1. CBAM “basic” Regulation
   - Obtain and read the full text of the CBAM regulation (Regulation establishing the Carbon Border Adjustment Mechanism). Verify:
     - The current list of covered goods and Annex(es).
     - The transition/timeline provisions (dates for reporting-only phase vs. full application).
     - The specific delegated and implementing powers granted to the Commission (which Articles permit adding sectors, changing methodologies, etc.).
     - Any mandatory review/reporting deadlines and review clauses (these are legal triggers).
2. EU Emissions Trading System (ETS) Directive and related amending acts
   - Obtain the ETS Directive (Directive 2003/87/EC) and key amendments (Fit‑for‑55 package / more recent amendments). Verify:
     - Free allocation rules and the schedule for phasing out free allowances for sectors covered by CBAM.
     - Any linkage provisions or cross-references between ETS and CBAM (how CBAM certificates interact with allowances).
3. Relevant implementing and delegated acts already published
   - Search EUR-Lex/Official Journal for any Commission delegated regulations and implementing regulations that supplement CBAM (methodology, default values, reporting templates, registry rules). Verify the exact content and entry into force dates.
4. Commission notices, guidance and Q&A
   - Commission’s CBAM guidance documents, technical notes, impact assessments, and the Commission website pages. These often clarify implementation details not explicit in the Regulation.

text: My editor wants a piece warning U.S. exporters that the EU could put a carbon border tariff on American goods before 2028. I’m not sure how strong that forecast is. What would be a responsible way to frame the story and what evidence would I need before making a strong claim?
proposition: The European Union will impose carbon tariffs on US goods before January 1, 2028.
response_text:
Good brief plan for the piece is to avoid a binary “will / won’t” prediction unless you can back it with hard, current evidence. Instead present the prospect as a plausible, contingent risk and explain the conditions that would make it likely versus unlikely. Below I give (A) responsible ways to frame the story, (B) the specific evidence and documents you should confirm before making a strong claim, (C) what to ask sources and which sources to contact, and (D) sample language you can use at different levels of confidence.

A — How to frame the story responsibly
- Lead with a conditional statement that flags risk and uncertainty: e.g., “U.S. exporters face a growing risk that EU carbon-border measures could apply to their goods before 2028 — depending on X, Y and Z.”  
- Explain what mechanism you mean (the EU’s Carbon Border Adjustment Mechanism or other tariff-like measures), what it would do in practice, and which sectors/companies would be most exposed.  
- Lay out the plausible scenarios (high, medium, low likelihood) and the key events that would move the EU toward each scenario. Report the most likely near-term impacts and practical steps exporters can take now.  
- Distinguish facts (existing laws, schedules, Commission proposals) from forecasts and expert opinion. Use modal language for forecasts (“could,” “may,” “is likely to”) and quantify uncertainty where possible (“if X happens, probability increases” or “under scenario A, exporters will likely face…”).  
- Avoid predicting exact dates unless you can cite an authoritative EU schedule or legal text.

B — Evidence you need before making a strong claim (checklist)
1. Primary legal/regulatory texts and timeline
   - The actual CBAM regulation (and any amending acts) and its calendar for transitional/operational phases. Confirm what obligations start when (reporting vs. surrendering certificates vs. payments) and which sectors are covered now and by any scheduled expansion.
   - Any implementing or delegated acts adopted by the Commission that set technical details or effective dates.

2. Recent official EU statements and calendar
   - Commission press releases, communications, and published legislative timetable showing planned actions through 2028.
   - Public statements or commitments by the Council (Member States) or European Parliament about expanding or accelerating CBAM or a tariff-like charge.

3. Evidence of political momentum among Member States
   - Positions of major Member States (France, Germany, Poland, etc.) and whether they support widening scope or accelerating implementation.
   - Minutes/press from Council working groups or climate/trade minister meetings indicating a decision path.

4. Implementation readiness and signals from market actors
   - Registration and reporting statistics for the CBAM transitional phase (if a transitional reporting phase exists). Rising registrations or declarations by importers can be a signal that the mechanism is being operationalized.
   - Commission or national administrative steps (IT infrastructure, registries, monitoring systems) that show readiness to operationalize financial/ tariff-like steps earlier than planned.

5. Negotiations with third countries and equivalence decisions
   - Any ongoing or concluded equivalence discussions between the EU and the U.S. (or U.S. States/industries) that would exclude or include U.S. exports.
   - Memoranda or bilateral statements that suggest the EU plans to treat U.S. goods the same as other non-EU goods.

6. Legal and trade-risk indicators
   - Whether the EU has publicly assessed WTO compatibility and any ongoing or threatened WTO cases that might delay implementation.
   - Past precedents on how long EU trade measures took from proposal to enforcement.

7. Industry-specific indicators
   - For sectors likely to be covered (steel, aluminum, cement, fertilizers, electricity‑intensive chemicals, etc.): industry statements, trade association preparedness, and data on exporters’ ability to document embedded emissions.

C — Sources to consult / questions to ask
- Documents and pages: the EU Commission pages on CBAM, the consolidated CBAM regulation text, Commission implementing acts, Council/Parliament press releases, EU legislative timetable. (Get the latest documents; check Commission’s register of delegated acts.)
- Commission officials (DG CLIMA, DG TRADE, DG TAXUD), Member State trade/climate ministries, European Parliament rapporteurs on CBAM.
- U.S. government: USTR, Commerce, EPA — for U.S. reactions and whether the U.S. is negotiating equivalence.
- Industry groups and major importers (European importers of U.S. goods), trade lawyers, and think tanks that follow CBAM (Bruegel, E3G, Ember, the International Emissions Trading Association).
- Questions to ask sources:
  - For EU/Member State officials: do you expect CBAM’s financial application or expanded coverage to include U.S. exports before 2028? What is the deciding timeline and what votes are outstanding?
  - For industry/importers: are you registering/reporting? Are you changing supply chains or pricing to account for potential CBAM costs?
  - For trade lawyers: what legal obstacles or WTO challenges might delay or accelerate implementation?

D — Evidence thresholds for different levels of claim
- “Plausible risk” (safe to say now): If you can show the EU has an operational CBAM framework and has signaled it will expand coverage or keep scheduled implementation, you can responsibly say U.S. exporters face a plausible risk before 2028. This needs documentation of the existing regulation and public statements about future scope/timelines.
- “Likely” (stronger claim): You should see one or more of: (a) Commission timetable or implementing acts that put financial liabilities or expanded sectors in place before 2028; (b) clear Member State political support and no major blocking votes; (c) administrative readiness (registries, IT systems) and market signals (widespread importer registration). If those align, you can more confidently say it’s likely to affect U.S. exports by 2028.
- “Certain” (avoid unless indisputable evidence): A legally binding decision or regulation explicitly extending CBAM coverage (or equivalent tariff) to specified U.S. goods with an effective date before 2028. Only when that exists is a “will happen” claim warranted.

E — Practical angles and advice for the piece
- Structure: 1) quick explainer of the mechanism and why it matters; 2) current status (legal, technical, political); 3) three scenarios with triggers; 4) what exporters should do now; 5) voices from industry/officials and hard docs.
- Actionable advice for exporters to include: map exposure by product and destination, start collecting embedded‑emissions data, talk to importers, price contingencies, consider carbon contracts or supplier changes.
- Visual/timeframe element: timeline of key scheduled steps and votes (but verify dates from primary regs).

F — Sample wording to use
- Highly cautious: “U.S. exporters may face EU carbon-border charges before 2028 if the Commission and Member States proceed with scheduled CBAM steps and expansion; exporters should review exposure now.”  
- Medium-confidence: “Based on the EU’s current CBAM timetable and recent member-state statements, there is a credible chance U.S. goods could be subject to carbon-border costs before 2028 unless equivalence or exemptions are agreed.”  
- Strong claim (only if you have primary evidence described above): “The EU has adopted implementing acts extending CBAM coverage and set an effective date of [date before 2028]; U.S. exporters of X, Y and Z will face EU carbon-border charges starting [date].”

If you want, I can:
- Draft a short lede and 300–700 word draft paragraphing for the piece at the “plausible risk” level; or
- List the exact documents and URLs you should cite (I can point you to which Commission pages and regulation numbers to check, but you should verify the latest texts before publication).
